transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by discussing your experience with the behavioral experiment we set last time. Can you tell me how it went and what you learned from it?

Patient: Well, I decided to attend a small gathering at my neighbor's house. I was really nervous about going, but I reminded myself of the prediction log we created and tried to keep an open mind.

Therapist: That's great that you challenged yourself and attended the gathering despite your initial nervousness. What were some of the predictions you made before going, and how did the actual experience compare?

Patient: I predicted that I would feel awkward and out of place, and that people wouldn't want to talk to me. I also thought I might say something embarrassing or make a fool of myself. But when I got there, my neighbor introduced me to some of her friends, and they were all very welcoming. We had some nice conversations, and I even found out that one of the guests shares my interest in woodworking.

Therapist: It sounds like the actual experience was quite different from your initial predictions. What do you think this says about your negative beliefs related to social situations?

Patient: I guess it shows that my fears and assumptions aren't always accurate. Just because I feel nervous or unsure about a social situation doesn't mean it will turn out badly.

Therapist: Exactly, Mei. This is a great example of how our thoughts and beliefs can influence our emotions and behaviors, even when they're not based on facts. By testing out these beliefs through behavioral experiments, we can gather evidence to challenge them and develop more balanced and adaptive thoughts. How did you feel after attending the gathering and realizing that your predictions didn't come true?

Patient: I felt relieved and a bit more confident. It made me think that maybe I've been avoiding social situations unnecessarily and that I could be missing out on positive experiences.

Therapist: That's a really important insight, Mei. Avoidance is a common coping mechanism for anxiety and depression, but it often reinforces negative beliefs and prevents us from having experiences that could challenge those beliefs. As we continue with behavioral activation and experiments, you'll likely find more evidence that contradicts your negative beliefs and supports more balanced and adaptive thoughts.

Patient: I can see that now. It's just hard to push myself to do these things when I'm feeling down or anxious.

Therapist: I understand, Mei. It takes a lot of courage and effort to face your fears and challenge long-held beliefs. That's why we start with small, manageable goals and build up gradually. Speaking of goals, how have you been doing with setting small goals for behavioral activation?

Patient: It's been a struggle. I know that setting small goals can help me build momentum and feel a sense of accomplishment, but I often find myself feeling overwhelmed or unmotivated.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, Mei. Let's explore this further. What do you think makes it difficult for you to set and work towards small goals?

Patient: I think part of it is my perfectionism. I tend to set really high standards for myself, and if I can't meet them, I feel like a failure. So sometimes it feels easier to not try at all than to risk falling short.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Mei. Perfectionism can be a significant barrier to motivation and goal-setting. It's important to recognize that perfectionism is often driven by unrealistic standards and all-or-nothing thinking, which are types of cognitive distortions. In reality, progress is rarely perfect or linear, and small steps are still valuable and worthwhile. What do you think would happen if you set more realistic, achievable goals for yourself?

Patient: I guess I would feel less overwhelmed and more motivated to actually work towards them. And even if I didn't reach them perfectly, I could still see that I'm making progress.

Therapist: Exactly, Mei. By setting realistic, achievable goals, you can build momentum and self-efficacy, which can help counteract feelings of worthlessness and lack of motivation. It's also important to practice self-compassion and recognize that setbacks and imperfections are a normal part of the process. What's one small goal related to behavioral activation that you could set for yourself this week?

Patient: I could aim to spend 30 minutes each day working on a woodworking project, even if I don't feel motivated at first. And if I don't finish the project perfectly, I can try to be kind to myself and focus on the progress I've made.

Therapist: That sounds like a great goal, Mei. Remember to break it down into smaller steps if needed, and to acknowledge and celebrate your efforts along the way. As you work towards this goal, pay attention to any negative thoughts or beliefs that arise, and practice challenging them using the thought record technique we've been working on.
